sen.j: 東郷 重位（とうごう ちゅうい/しげかた、永禄4年（1561年） - 寛永20年6月27日 (旧暦)（1643年8月11日））は薩摩藩の武士にして示現流剣術の流祖。
sen.e: Chui (also known as Shigekata) TOGO (1561 - August 11, 1643) was a samurai in the Satsuma Clan and the founder of the Jigen school of swordsmanship.
Chui (also known as Shigekata) TOGO (1561 - August 11, 1643) was a samurai in the Satsuma Clan and the founder of the Jigen school of swordsmanship.
Chui (also known as Shigekata) TOGO (1561 - August 11, 1643) was a samurai in the Satsuma clan and the founder of the Jigen school of swordsmanship.

sen.j: 幼名は弥十郎、通称は藤兵衛。
sen.e: Togo's childhood name was Yajuro but went by the name of Tobei.
Togo's childhood name was Yajuro but went by the name of Tobei.
Togo's childhood name was Yajuro but went by the name of Tobei.

sen.j: のち、長門守、和泉守、越前守、肥前守。
sen.e: Togo was later referred to as Nagato no kami, Izumi no kami, Echizen no kami or Hizen no kami.
Togo was later referred to as Nagato no kami, Izumi no kami, Echizen no kami or Hizen no kami.
Togo was later referred to as Nagato no kami, Izumi no kami, Echizen no kami or Hizen no kami.

sen.j: 諱は重位、示現流では口伝で「ちゅうい」とする。
sen.e: Togo's real name was Shigekata but, at the Jigen School, he was referred to as 'Chui.'
Togo's real name was Shigekata but, at the Jigen School, he was referred to as 'Chui.'
Togo's real name was Shigekata but, at the Jigen School, he was referred to as 'Chui.'

sen.j: 瀬戸口重為の三男。
sen.e: Togo was the third son of Shigetame SETOGUCHI.
Togo was the third son of Shigetame SETOGUCHI.
Togo was the third son of Shigetame SETOGUCHI.

sen.j: 瀬戸口家は北薩の土豪薩摩東郷氏の遠戚にあたり、同時代の史料には瀬戸口藤兵衛または瀬戸口肥前守の名で登場することがある。
sen.e: The Setoguchi family was a distant relative of the Togo clan, the powerful local clan in Satsuma, and Togo was mentioned as Tobei SETOGUCHI or Setoguchi Hizen no kami in historical papers covering that period.

The Setoguchi family was a distant relative of the Togo clan, the powerful local clan in Satsuma, and Togo was mentioned as Tobei SETOGUCHI or Setoguchi Hizen no kami in historical papers covering that period.

The Setoguchi family was a distant relative of the Togo clan, the powerful local clan in Satsuma, and Togo was mentioned as Tobei SETOGUCHI or Setoguchi Hizen no kami in historical papers covering that period.

sen.j: 天正年間に兄の東郷重治とともに東郷氏嫡家17代目東郷重虎の許可をもらい、東郷氏に複姓した。
sen.e: During the Tensho era, Togo, along with his older brother Shigeharu TOGO, adopted the surname of Togo upon the approval of Shigetora TOGO who was the 17th head of the main line of the house of Togo.
During the Tensho era, Togo, along with his older brother Shigeharu TOGO, adopted the surname of Togo upon the approval of Shigetora TOGO who was the 17th head of the main line of the house of Togo.
During the Tensho era, Togo, along with his older brother Shigeharu TOGO, adopted the surname of Togo upon the approval of Shigetora TOGO who was the 17th head of the main line of the house of Togo.

sen.j: なお、外孫で古示現流開祖の種子島時貞の系図『種子島氏支族美座対馬守時里二男国上氏系図』（「伊地知季安著作集三」の『諸家系図文書四』の史料）では『東郷肥前重信』と表記されている。
sen.e: Additionally, according to the genealogy of Tokisada TANEGASHIM who was Chui's grandson and the founder of Kojigen school entitled "種子島氏支族美座対馬守時里二男国上氏系図" (the historical data found in諸家系図文書四 of the' Collection of the Writings of Sueyoshi Ijichi, Volume 3'), Chui's name was written as 'Togo Hizen Shigenobu.'
sen.cmt: 「種子島氏支族美座対馬守時里二男国上氏系図」ならびに「諸家系図文書四」 ― 読み・定訳不明、
sen.e: Additionally, according to the genealogy of Tokisada TANEGASHIM who was Chui's grandson and the founder of Kojigen school entitled "種子島氏支族美座対馬守時里二男国上氏系図" (the historical data found in諸家系図文書四 of the' Collection of the Writings of Sueyoshi Ijichi, Volume 3'), Chui's name was written as 'Togo Hizen Shigenobu.'

Additionally, according to the genealogy of Tokisada TANEGASHIMA who was Chui's grandson and the founder of Kojigen school entitled "種子島氏支族美座対馬守時里二男国上氏系図" (the historical data found in 諸家系図文書四 of the 'Collection of the Writings of Sueyoshi Ijichi, Volume 3'), Chui's name was written as "Togo Hizen Shigenobu."
sen.cmt: 全角削除スペース挿入

sen.j: 経歴
sen.e: Career
Career
Career

sen.j: 若い頃はタイ捨流を学んだ。
sen.e: Togo studied Taisha School in his youth.
Togo studied Taisha School in his youth.
Togo studied Taisha School in his youth.

sen.j: 天正6年（1578年）11月の大友氏との戦いである耳川の戦いが初陣で、薬丸兼成を親分として、首級をあげる。
sen.e: Togo went on his first campaign to the battle against the Otomo clan in November 1578 in which he severed the head of the main man Kaneshige YAKUMARU.
Togo went on his first campaign to the battle against the Otomo clan in November 1578 in which he severed the head of the main man Kaneshige YAKUMARU.
Togo went on his first campaign to the battle against the Otomo clan in December 1578 in which he severed the head of the main man Kaneshige YAKUMARU.

sen.j: 天正15年（1587年）、仕えていた島津氏が豊臣秀吉の前に敗北し、重位は島津義久に従って上洛する。
sen.e: In 1587, the Shimazu clan, Togo's lord, was defeated by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Chui (TOGO) followed Yoshihisa SHIMAZU to Kyoto.
In 1587, the Shimazu clan, Togo's lord, was defeated by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Chui (TOGO) followed Yoshihisa SHIMAZU to Kyoto.
In 1587, the Shimazu clan, Togo's lord, was defeated by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Chui (TOGO) followed Yoshihisa SHIMAZU to Kyoto.

sen.j: 本当の目的は内職のため金細工の修行をすることだったらしい。
sen.e: It seems that the real purpose of Togo's trip to Kyoto was to get trained on gold work to work on the side.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It seems that the real purpose of Togo's trip to Kyoto was to get trained on gold work to work on the side.
It seems that the real purpose of Togo's trip to Kyoto was to get trained on gold work to work on the side.

sen.j: しかしながら、天寧寺の善吉和尚に出会い彼の剣術（天真正自顕流）に開眼、修行の後薩摩に帰国する。
sen.e: A chance encounter with Zenkichi Osho of Tennei-ji Temple, however, opened Togo's eyes to swordsmanship (Tenshinshojiken School) and he returned to Satsuma after training under Zenkichi Osho.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文例外対処
sen.e: A chance encounter with Zenkichi Osho of Tennei-ji Temple, however, opened Togo's eyes to swordsmanship (Tenshinshojiken School) and he returned to Satsuma after training under Zenkichi Osho.
A chance encounter with Zenkichi Osho of Tennei-ji Temple, however, opened Togo's eyes to swordsmanship (Tenshinshojiken School) and he returned to Satsuma after training under Zenkichi Osho.

sen.j: 帰国の後、天正17年（1589年）、国分郷の鳥越に帰る。
sen.e: After returning to Satsuma, Togo went back to Torigoe in Kokubu go in 1589.
After returning to Satsuma, Togo went back to Torigoe in Kokubu go in 1589.
After returning to Satsuma, Togo went back to Torigoe in Kokubu go in 1589.

sen.j: 天真正自顕流に元々学んでいたタイ捨流の技術を組み合わせて独自の創意工夫を加えていった。
sen.e: Togo added his own ingenuity to swordsmanship by combining the techniques of Tenshinshojiken School and Taisha School that he had studied earlier.
Togo added his own ingenuity to swordsmanship by combining the techniques of Tenshinshojiken School and Taisha School that he had studied earlier.
Togo added his own ingenuity to swordsmanship by combining the techniques of Tenshinshojiken School and Taisha School that he had studied earlier.

sen.j: 庄内の乱の勃発した慶長4年（1599年）頃には島津家中内に既に大勢の門人をかかえていた。
sen.e: By the time when the Shonai War broke out in 1599, Togo already had numerous pupils in the house of Shimazu.
By the time the Shonai War broke out in 1599, Togo already had numerous pupils in the house of Shimazu.
By the time the Shonai War broke out in 1599, Togo already had numerous pupils in the house of Shimazu.

sen.j: やがてその名声が島津忠恒に聞こえるところとなり、慶長9年（1604年）、忠恒の御前試合でタイ捨流の剣術師範を破り、島津家兵法師範となる。
sen.e: Before long, Tadatsune SHIMAZU came to hear about Togo's reputation and, in 1640, Togo won the competition against the grand master of the Taisha School of swordsmanship performed before Tadatsune whereby becoming the grand master of the art of warfare for the Shimazu Family.

Before long, Tadatsune SHIMAZU came to hear about Togo's reputation and, in 1640, Togo won the competition against the grand master of the Taisha School of swordsmanship performed before Tadatsune whereby becoming the grand master of the art of warfare for the Shimazu Family.

Before long, Tadatsune SHIMAZU came to hear about Togo's reputation and, in 1640, Togo won the competition against the grand master of the Taisha School of swordsmanship performed before Tadatsune whereby becoming the grand master of the art of warfare for the Shimazu family.

sen.j: ちなみにこのとき逆上した忠恒を一刀のもとに打ち伏せたという逸話も伝わる。
sen.e: There is an anecdote that Chui beat the raging Tadatsune with a single sweep of sword at that time.
There is an anecdote that Chui beat the raging Tadatsune with a single sweep of sword at that time.
There is an anecdote that Chui beat the raging Tadatsune with a single sweep of sword at that time.

sen.j: その後、南浦文之により「示現流」という流派名を命名される。
sen.e: Bunshi NANBO subsequently named Togo's art of swordsmanship 'Jigen School.'
Bunshi NANBO subsequently named Togo's art of swordsmanship 'Jigen School.'
Bunshi NANBO subsequently named Togo's art of swordsmanship 'Jigen School.'

sen.j: 「慶長15年9月22日 九満崎御宮作ニ付すすめ日記」に「同（真米）壱升 東郷長門守殿」とある。
sen.e: In 九満崎御宮作ニ付すすめ日記 entered on November 7, 1610, it is written, 'Likewise (Rice) 1.8 liters, Togo Nagato no kami.'
sen.cmt: 九満崎御宮作ニ付すすめ日記－読み・定訳不明
sen.e: In 九満崎御宮作ニ付すすめ日記 entered on November 7, 1610, it is written, 'Likewise (Rice) 1.8 liters, Togo Nagato no kami.'
In 九満崎御宮作ニ付すすめ日記 entered on November 7, 1610, it is written, 'Likewise (Rice) 1.8 liters, Togo Nagato no kami.'

sen.j: きわめて礼儀正しく、物事を荒立てない人格者であったといわれ、薩摩藩家老から島津家内部の密事に関わる相談事を受けることも多々あった。
sen.e: It is said that Chui was a polite and gentle person of integrity often sought to be consulted by the chief retainer of the Satsuma Clan on sensitive matters within the Shimazu Family.
It is said that Chui was a polite and gentle person of integrity often sought to be consulted by the chief retainer of the Satsuma Clan on sensitive matters within the Shimazu Family.
It is said that Chui was a polite and gentle person of integrity often sought to be consulted by the chief retainer of the Satsuma clan on sensitive matters within the Shimazu family.

sen.j: 後に薩摩藩密貿易の拠点とも言われた坊津（現在の南さつま市坊津町）の地頭となったところからみても、剣術だけの人物でなかったことは確かである。
sen.e: Considering that Chui was made the jito (manager and lord of manor) of Bonotsu (the present Bonotsu-cho, Minami-Satsuma City), there is no doubt that he was more than just an excellent swordsman.
Considering that Chui was made the jito (manager and lord of manor) of Bonotsu (the present Bonotsu-cho, Minami-Satsuma City), there is no doubt that he was more than just an excellent swordsman.

Considering that Chui was made the jito (manager and lord of manor) of Bonotsu (present-day Bonotsu-cho, Minami-Satsuma City), which was later to become known as a smuggling center of the Satsuma clan, there is no doubt that he was more than just an excellent swordsman.
sen.cmt: 赤字部分の訳漏れ対応しました。

sen.j: また、「坊郷地頭職就任時に鹿児島城下に宅地2反3畦17部半を賜る」と「平姓東郷氏支族系図」にあり、地頭就任時に国分を去ったと推測される。
sen.e: Additionally, as it was recorded in 平姓東郷氏支族系図 that 'when Chui assumed the position of the jito of Bonotsu, he was given approximately 2400 square meters (or 0..24 hectare) of land near Kagoshima Castle by his lord,'it is presumed that Chui left Kokubun when he became the jito.
sen.cmt: 平姓東郷氏支族系図 ― 読み・定訳不明
sen.e: Additionally, as it was recorded in 平姓東郷氏支族系図 that 'when Chui assumed the position of the jito of Bonotsu, he was given approximately 2400 square meters (or 0..24 hectare) of land near Kagoshima Castle by his lord,'it is presumed that Chui left Kokubun when he became the jito.

Additionally, as it was recorded in 平姓東郷氏支族系図 that 'when Chui assumed the position of the jito of Bonotsu, he was given approximately 2400 square meters (or 0.24 hectare) of land near Kagoshima-jo Castle by his lord,' it is presumed that Chui left Kokubun when he became the jito.

sen.j: 重位の石高は400石。
sen.e: Kokudaka (stipend) Chui earned was 400 koku.
Kokudaka (stipend) Chui earned was 400 koku.
Kokudaka (stipend) Chui earned was 400 koku.

sen.j: 島津忠恒ははじめ1000石を授けようとしたが、重位は思うところあって600石を返還している。
sen.e: Tadatsune SHIMAZU initially gave Chui 1000 koku but, for some reason, Chui returned 600 koku.
Tadatsune SHIMAZU initially gave Chui 1000 koku but, for some reason, Chui returned 600 koku.
Tadatsune SHIMAZU initially gave Chui 1000 koku but, for some reason, Chui returned 600 koku.

sen.j: 隠居後、100石を与えられた。
sen.e: After retiring, Chui was given 100 koku.
After retiring, Chui was given 100 koku.
After retiring, Chui was given 100 koku.

sen.j: 墓所は曹洞宗南林寺 (鹿児島市)。
sen.e: Chui's grave site is located on the grounds of Nanrin-ji Temple, Soto sect (Kagoshima City).
Chui's grave site is located on the grounds of Nanrin-ji Temple, Soto sect (Kagoshima City).
Chui's grave site is located on the grounds of Nanrin-ji Temple, Soto sect (Kagoshima City).

sen.j: 法名は能学俊芸庵主。
sen.e: Chui's posthumous Buddhist name is Nogakushungei anju.
sen.cmt: 能学俊芸庵主 －読み不明
sen.e: Chui's posthumous Buddhist name is Nogakushungei anju.
Chui's posthumous Buddhist name is Nogakushungei anju.

sen.j: 家族・親族
sen.e: Family and Relations
Family and Relations
Family and relations

sen.j: 兄弟：瀬戸口弥左衛門、東郷重治
sen.e: Brothers: Yazaeemon SETOGUCHI and Shigeharu TOGO
Brothers: Yazaeemon SETOGUCHI and Shigeharu TOGO
Brothers: Yazaeemon SETOGUCHI and Shigeharu TOGO

sen.j: 妻：松本（あるいは松元）伊予の娘
sen.e: Wife: the daughter of Iyo MATSUMOTO (also known as MATSUMOTO written in different kanji)
Wife: the daughter of Iyo MATSUMOTO (also known as MATSUMOTO written in different kanji)
Wife: the daughter of Iyo MATSUMOTO (also known as MATSUMOTO written in different kanji)

sen.j: 子：1男3女〔北郷久利の妻、和田正貞の妻、東郷重方、堀興延の妻〕
sen.e: Children: 1 son and 3 daughters (the wife of Hisatoshi HONGO, the wife of Masasada WADA, Shigemasa TOGO and the wife of Okinobu HORI)
Children: 1 son and 3 daughters (the wife of Hisatoshi HONGO, the wife of Masasada WADA, Shigemasa TOGO and the wife of Okinobu HORI)
